posts.name: Topsail Robotics
posts.cooked:
Hey there! Thanks for stopping to help! We’re team 9297 trying to wire a retroreflective photoelectric sensor to our robo rio 2. The sensor is Banner’s Q20ND sensor. The info can be found on it if u search it up. The input voltage is 10-30 v. It is 4 wire NPN which makes it confusing. I’m also not 100% sure because it’s over the 5v for the rio ports (We are using REV PDP if that’s what we need to connect it to). Refer to photo for rest of info. Any help is appreciated! Thx! (We also need to only get an output from this sensor that will say on) image 3024×4032 3.37 MB

image 3024×4032 3.37 MB

image 3024×4032 3.37 MB

posts.name: Topsail Robotics
posts.cooked: We’ll be back at 3:30 EST the 28th! We’ll try to answer before then but can’t test.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
So the blue and the brown are your “negative” and “positive” respectfully. These will be attached to any 12v source. This can be a VRM , the 12v off of the PDH , etc (just makes sure you are using approved wire gauges for the PDP )

The other two wires are signal wires. White is normally closed (signal when the sensor isn’t triggered). Blue is normally open (no signal when sensor isn’t triggered). One of these wires would go to the signal pin on a digital I/O channel on the RIO. It doesn’t really matter which one you use as you can invert the output in code (just cover the unused wire end  (blue or white) with some electrical tape ) . ( Edit, see below comments on the voltage not getting low enough, for this reason you may want to use the normally open wire (black) as your signal. )

In code the sensor will function just like any limit switch or other digital input. You may need to adjust the gain with a small screwdriver to tune the sensor to your application.

link_counts.title: 1678 Citrus Circuits 2025 CAD, Code and Strategy Release

posts.name: Eric Tate
posts.cooked: Since these sensors can be powered by 10 to 30Vdc, I suggest using 24Vdc from the output of a PCM to a valid any issues with brown outs. This is what we are doing with our through beam sensors. The PCM outputs are coded to be on all of the time.

posts.name: Nicholas
posts.cooked: While this is in theory a better option, it is not necessary, and a bit bulky if you are not already using a pneumatic control module. To compensate for VBAT dipping below 12v, you can run it on a 12v buck/boost regulator with a low cutoff voltage, or a 12v output of CTRE ’s VRM .

The VRM has worked well for us. I would note that with industrial sensors from automation direct we have seen that the npn output does not sink low enough to work with the robo rio dio. The banner sensor spec sheet indicates low level to be less than 3v and the rio expects less than 0.8v. We are using 12v-5v level converters to overcome this. In a pinch using an analog input and an external pull-up resistor may suffice.

posts.name: Eric Tate
posts.cooked: We have not had this issue when using NPN Open Collector Output sensors both from Banner previously and this year Contrinex (from Automation Direct). The open collector output simply pulls the DIO low (the RIO DIOs have internal pull up resistors). It is not even 100% necessary to patch over a common to the RIO since common is common even when using a boost converter like the PCM .
Interesting. Maybe I’ll try some other sensors.

posts.name: Topsail Robotics
posts.cooked: Thanks to everyone for the help! Sounds like we will be wiring it up how Skyhawk mentioned through the PCM (We don’t have any other easy ways to boost the voltage). Didn’t know the roborio had internal pull up on the DIO either! We’ll report back on how it goes!

posts.name: Eric Tate
posts.cooked: You just need to remenber to only connect the Open Collector output to the DIO without a pull-up resistor to the 12V or 24V supply as they will show you in the sensor connection diagram. You don’t want the supply voltage getting to the DIO. I hope I explained that clearly.

posts.name: sanddrag
posts.cooked:
I’m using this relay board. https://www.amazon.com/HiLetgo-Channel-Isolation-Support-Trigger/dp/B00LW15D1M/

Relay response time is <10ms.

I’m using a SICK sensor, but a Banner or any other industrial sensor should work just the same way.

Here’s how it’s wired. IMG_20240204_134926863 1920×1446 161 KB

link_counts.title: How do I program a banner photoelectric sensor into our program

posts.name: Topsail Robotics
posts.cooked: Hey! what would it look like to wire the bot if you did not have the VRM and no relay? I’ll send a photo of what we currently have available,

posts.name: sanddrag
posts.cooked: Most Automation sensors are 10-30VDC. My sensor still worked down to about 8V, but started to drop out below that. Robot voltage can take a dip when accelerating hard so you really want a regulated source ideally. If you don’t have a VRM , just give it 12V from anywhere on the PDH , smallest breaker preferably. Just know that it may brown out if your robot voltage dips below 10V or so.
